data.title: Stock Market Today: Apple, Amazon Spearhead a Wild Tech Rally
data.text: Investors continued to hold out hope for an additional federal stimulus package Monday even after the weekend saw both parties rip the White House's $1.8 trillion counteroffer, with Senate Republicans calling the amount too much and Democrats decrying it as too little. But stocks nonetheless headed higher on the back of a massive push from a few tech stocks.

data.title: Don't have to own all Big Tech names, but want to have exposure: Jason Ware
data.text: Joanna Stern, WSJ senior personal tech columnist, and Jason Ware, Albion Financial Group chief investment officer, join 'Power Lunch' to discuss how investors should be positioned in the tech space and how tech regulation could affect the stocks.

data.text: Amazon’s Jeff Bezos and President Trump hate each other. But they should be best friends because of how the coronavirus dramatically raised the profile of AMZN stock.

data.text: SpartanNash (SPTN) issues a stock warrant that enables Amazon to purchase up to 5.4 million of its common shares.

data.text: The start of the holiday shopping season has been creeping up for years as America's biggest retailers fight to win customers with early deals in stores and online.

data.title: AMZN Soars on Prime Day Before Holidays: Should Others Worry?
data.text: Amazon (AMZN) gears up for the holiday season with the second Prime Day event this year. This is intensifying the battle for retailers like Walmart and Target.

data.title: Not all tech companies are the same, said NYTimes' Tom Friedman on regulation

data.title: MANA Stocks vs. FANG Stocks: 2 Years Later

data.title: Amazon’s first-ever fall Prime Day brings new challenges in the midst of a tumultuous year
data.text: Amazon and its army of logistics workers are bracing for the first-ever fall Prime Day starting Tuesday, as the extraordinary circumstances of 2020 bring new challenges for a shopping event that has become key for Amazon’s e-commerce business.

data.title: FT: The EU is taking aim at Big Tech with a "hit list" of tougher regulations
data.text: Javier Espinoza, correspondent for the Financial Times covering EU competition and digital policy, discusses his reporting on how regulators are making a "hit list" of up to 20 large internet companies, including Facebook and Google, that may face new rules aimed at curbing their market dominance.
